title: Click
descriptions:
Click (2006) follows Michael Newman, an overworked architect in New York struggling to balance his ambition with family life. Eager to impress his demanding boss, Mr. Ammer, and secure a long-awaited promotion, Michael continually sacrifices time with his loving wife Donna and their two kids, Ben and Samantha. The stress of juggling career pressure and home responsibilities leaves him exhausted, resentful, and convinced that if he can just get through the “tough parts” now, he’ll have time for family later.

One night, frustrated by a tangle of remote controls and the sense that he has no control over his life, Michael goes to a Bed Bath & Beyond. In a mysterious back room labeled “Beyond,” he meets an eccentric clerk named Morty, who offers him a free, experimental universal remote. Michael soon realizes it can control reality like a television: pausing, muting, rewinding, and fast-forwarding his life. Initially amused, he uses it for petty conveniences—muting the neighbor’s barking dog, pausing arguments, and replaying a fight to “win” it. The remote also contains a “Menu” that lets him revisit past memories, where he sees formative moments with his parents and the early days with Donna, reminding him of the warmth he’s drifted from.

When faced with frustrations—illness, work drudgery, marital spats—Michael starts fast-forwarding. The remote’s AI begins to “learn” his preferences, skipping similar experiences automatically. What starts as a time-saver becomes a trap: months, then years vanish without his conscious participation. He blinks and finds his career has advanced, but the costs are staggering. He’s gained weight, has marital strain, and his kids are older, distant. Every time he tries to take control, the remote jumps ahead again at the slightest trigger—an argument, a cold, a busy season—ripping him past irreplaceable moments.

Michael’s career breakthrough finally arrives: he becomes a partner at the firm, while his mentor Ammer retires and Michael reports to the slick, cutthroat Janine. But the personal toll grows worse. Donna, unable to endure years of neglect, divorces him and marries a kinder man, Bill, their former family friend. Ben, once eager for his father’s attention, becomes a work-consumed executive mirroring Michael’s worst habits. Samantha feels sidelined and guarded. Michael tries to reconnect, but the remote keeps skipping the “boring” parts, hurling him to milestones he barely experiences: promotions, illnesses, surgeries, holidays, and funerals.

He fast-forwards to his ultimate promotion and discovers his father, Ted, has died—an event the remote deemed a “routine” family tragedy to skip. In a wrenching scene, Michael rewinds to a memory of his dad visiting him at work with a playful trick and genuine affection. Michael, distracted and impatient, had brushed him off. Watching from outside the moment, he realizes his father’s warmth and the finality of what he’s lost, breaking down with regret.

As time jumps spiral, Michael ends up in a future where his health has deteriorated, he’s divorced, Donna has rebuilt a happy home, and his relationship with his children is strained. After collapsing, he wakes in a hospital to learn he has a heart condition. Morty reappears, revealing himself as more than a quirky salesman—he’s the Angel of Death, guiding Michael through a harsh lesson about choices, time, and priorities. Morty explains that the remote only followed Michael’s implicit wishes; it didn’t create the neglect, it amplified it.

Desperate to change course, Michael flees the hospital during a storm to stop Donna from driving away with Bill and the kids. In a rain-soaked confrontation outside a hospital where Ben is now a high-powered executive, Michael collapses but uses his last strength to urge Ben not to repeat his mistakes: family first, work second. He tells Donna she was always the love of his life. He dies in the street, content that he delivered the message.

Suddenly, Michael wakes up in a display bed at Bed Bath & Beyond, as if everything were a dream. He rushes home and, in a flurry of relief and gratitude, changes his behavior: he cancels work, plans family time, kisses Donna passionately, and cherishes the small moments. Back in his closet, he finds the same remote and a note from Morty: “Good choice.” Michael tosses the remote in the trash, symbolically rejecting the shortcut through life.

Click blends broad comedy with a cautionary fable about time and attention. The fantastical remote, initially a comedic device for controlling nuisances, reveals how skipping discomfort also skips growth, love, and memory.
